item.title: not my circus, not my monkeys
item.description: image_small My wife is Polish, which means she doesn’t mince her words, and can be very direct, issuing requests and commands without the usual English fluff; “Would you mind doing…”, “Could you…”, “Have you thought about doing…”. Despite this directness of language, it turns out that the Poles have some wonderfully vivid and imaginative idioms and phrases in everyday use. I decided to document a small selection here, to give you an impression of the colourful Polish language.

item.title: mind expanding youtube
item.description: Every now and then, especially when I’m working my way through a weeks worth of ironing, I think to myself, ‘is there anything I could watch on YouTube that might expand my mind a little, to ease the pain of endless ironing?’. Of course, there is. YouTube appears as an infinite repository of content, ranging from the most gloriously intriguing content to utter pointlessness. And kittens. Here’s a little taster of the kind of YouTube content that has blown my mind…

item.title: non-digital knowledge stores (books)
item.description: It may be a bit square to refer to keep a library of books in this day and age, but I find books to be reassuringly apocalypse-resistant repositories of knowledge, often with far clearer and more understandable explanations than you’ll find on most statistics and data science web pages. Here’s a small sample of my statistics books: “Applied Statistics: Principles and Examples” by D.R.Cox and E.J.Snell (Chapman & Hall, 1981) “Problem Solving: A Statistician’s Guide” by C.
